query: What methods are available to control disease and sea lice in Atlantic salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates several methods: Fallowing between production cycles has been associated with lower sea lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in Scotland, though one Australian study found no difference in Amoebic Gill Disease (AGD) mortality (1026). Using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents showed mixed results: corkwing and goldsinny wrasse matched chemical treatments in controlling lice in one controlled study, while rockcook wrasse were ineffective in a replicated, controlled study (738). Freshwater bathing for AGD produced mixed outcomes in Australia: one study found reduced amoebae on gills lasting up to 10 days, while a replicated, controlled study found no difference from untreated fish (739). Altering lighting reduced lice loads in a replicated, controlled Norway study, with lower lice under low-intensity artificial or natural light and higher lice under more intense artificial light (741). Dietary approaches including probiotics, plant-based protein inclusion, and immunostimulants showed benefits: in Scotland, probiotics increased survival after bacterial challenges; in Norway, a diet with 28% plant protein reduced lice infection by 28% and adding beta-glucans reduced lice a further 28%; mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function and prevented soybean-induced enteritis (732). Vaccinations increased survival against multiple pathogens in controlled studies from Iceland, Norway, Australia, and Canada, including Aeromonas salmonicida spp. achromogenes, Yersinia ruckeri, marine flexibacteriosis, bacterial kidney disease, and infectious salmon anaemia (733). Selective breeding for resistance improved survival under infectious pancreatic necrosis exposure in a replicated, controlled Norway study (735).

tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "732",
  "action_title": "Use of probiotics and immunostimulants",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

One replicated study in Scotland found increased survival in salmon fed a probiotic before exposure to four different disease-causing bacteria over a 28 day period compared with controls.
A replicated, controlled study in Norway found the number of salmon infected with lice was reduced by 28% when fed a diet composed of fish meal and 28% plant-based protein. Adding beta-glucans to the diet decreased lice infection levels by a further 28% compared with controls.
The same study found the addition of mannan oligosaccharides improved gut function by preventing the development of soybean-induced enteritis compared with controls."
}

tools_called.args: {"action_id":"733"}
tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "733",
  "action_title": "Use vaccinations",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:
 

Two controlled studies from Iceland and Norway found higher survival rates in vaccinated salmon compared to unvaccinated control groups. This was post exposure to the disease-causing bacteria, Aeromonas salmonicida spp.achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri, respectively.
Two controlled studies in Australia and Canadia reported higher survival in salmon infected with marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease, post vaccination.
Two controlled studies in Norway reported similar results for salmon vaccinated against infectious salmon anaemia."
}

query: How do plant-based and bacterial protein alternatives to fish meal compare in terms of their effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates in Norway?
relevant_summary: In Norway, replicated controlled studies on bacterial protein reported similar growth rates to 100% fish meal when up to 25% of fish meal was replaced, lower growth at 50% replacement, and higher growth at 18% and 36% bacterial protein compared to the control or a 4.5% bacterial protein diet [918]. For plant-based proteins, studies including those from Norway reported decreased growth rates with plant-protein inclusion, while other Norwegian studies reported similar growth rates compared to fish meal; additional Norwegian evidence reported both reduced and similar final body weights relative to fish meal diets [924].

tools_called.args: {"query_string":"plant-based protein alternatives to fish meal effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates Norway bacterial protein salmon feed", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"query_string":"plant-based protein alternatives to fish meal effect on Atlantic salmon growth rates Norway bacterial protein salmon feed", "k": 3, "offset": 3}
{"action_id":"918"}
{"action_id":"924"}
tools_called.return_val:
{
  "action_id": "924",
  "action_title": "Use an alternative protein source: plant-based",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Six studies (four replicated, controlled) in Norway, Scotland and the USA found that inclusion of plant-based proteins within feed led to decreased growth rates in salmon. Three replicated and/or controlled studies from Norway, Canada and Scotland found similar growth rates in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal-based diets. Two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights in salmon fed either plant-based or fish meal diets.
Two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) from Norway found lowered levels of feeding efficiency, whereas a replicated study in Norway found increased levels of feeding efficiency in salmon fed plant-based protein diets compared to fish meal diets. Two replicated studies (one controlled) in Canada and Scotland study found similar levels of feeding efficiency across both diet types.
Digestibility of feed components by salmon was found to be lower in two replicated, controlled studies when the diets contained plant proteins compared to fish meal. Similar levels of digestibility across both diet types were identified by two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway. 
Two of the studies found that survival rates and appetite were not affected by plant- or fish meal-based protein diets. However morphology of the distal intestine was altered in two randomised, replicated, controlled studies where salmon were fed diets containing plant-based proteins. Condition of the salmon was increased in plant-based protein diets in one randomised, replicated, controlled study but reduced in two other replicated studies."
}

For plant-based proteins, studies including those from Norway reported decreased growth rates with plant-protein inclusion, while other Norwegian studies reported similar growth rates compared to fish meal; additional Norwegian evidence reported both reduced and similar final body weights relative to fish meal diets [924].","action_ids":["918","924"]}

query: Which interventions appear most effective for increasing the survival rates of farmed salmon exposed to disease?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates: Vaccinations increased survival rates in multiple controlled studies after exposure to Aeromonas salmonicida spp. achromogenes and Yersinia ruckeri (Iceland, Norway), marine flexibacteriosis and bacterial kidney disease (Australia, Canada), and infectious salmon anaemia (Norway) [733]. Aerobic training increased survival following exposure to infectious pancreatic necrosis in a randomised, replicated, controlled study in Norway, with interval training more effective than continuous training [740]. Breeding for resistance traits increased survival in salmon families bred for high resistance to infectious pancreatic necrosis compared to low-resistance families in a replicated, controlled study in Norway [735].

query: What are the documented effects of using plant-based proteins in salmon feed in aquaculture operations in Norway and Scotland?
relevant_summary: Across replicated and controlled studies in Norway and Scotland, inclusion of plant-based proteins in salmon feeds has been associated with: decreased growth rates in several studies, though some studies reported similar growth to fish meal-based diets [924]; reduced final body weights in multiple studies, while other studies found no difference from fish meal-based diets [924]; mixed effects on feed efficiency, with some studies showing lower efficiency, one showing higher efficiency, and others showing no difference compared to fish meal diets [924]; mixed results for digestibility, with some studies finding lower digestibility of feed components and others reporting similar digestibility to fish meal diets [924]; no detected effects on survival rates or appetite in two studies [924]; altered distal intestinal morphology in two studies [924]; and mixed effects on fish condition, with one study reporting increased condition and two reporting reduced condition on plant-based protein diets [924].

query: What are the non-chemical alternatives for controlling sea lice on salmon farms?
relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents identifies several non-chemical approaches: using cleaner wrasse as natural control agents, with mixed outcomes—one controlled study found corkwing and goldskinny cleaner wrasse were as effective as chemical treatments, while another replicated, controlled study found rockcook cleaner wrasse ineffective at preventing outbreaks [738]. Altering lighting, with a replicated, controlled study in Norway reporting lower lice numbers under low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting, and higher lice numbers under more intense artificial light [741]. Implementing fallowing, with a study in Scotland recording lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system, though another study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease when fallowing was used [1026].

query: How does the effectiveness of fallowing salmon farm cages for disease control vary between studies in Scotland and Australia?
relevant_summary: A study in Scotland recorded lower lice numbers on Atlantic salmon in cages using a fallowing system [1026]. In contrast, a study in Australia found no difference in mortality from Amoebic Gill Disease in cages where a fallowing system had been used [1026].

query: How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?
relevant_summary: Two replicated studies in Norway reported similar final weight gain between Atlantic salmon fed fishmeal or krill meal; when krill were de-shelled, growth rates were closer to fishmeal than with whole krill, and feed conversion ratios were similar between fishmeal and krill meal [916]. One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway found no differences in weight between salmon fed the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica and a fishmeal control [920]. One controlled, randomised, replicated study from Scotland showed fish fed a fishmeal diet weighed more than fish fed diets with alternative proteins [922].

{"action_id":"916"}

{"action_id":"922"}

{"query":"How do krill, yeast, and animal protein alternatives to fishmeal compare in their effect on Atlantic salmon growth?","summary":"Two replicated studies in Norway reported similar final weight gain between Atlantic salmon fed fishmeal or krill meal; when krill were de-shelled, growth rates were closer to fishmeal than with whole krill, and feed conversion ratios were similar between fishmeal and krill meal [916]. query: What is the evidence from studies in Norway for using alternative feed components in Atlantic salmon diets?
relevant_summary: In Norway, three controlled, replicated (two randomised) studies found no difference in growth rate of Atlantic salmon fed diets containing either genetically modified (GM) or non-GM soybeans, and one randomised, replicated, controlled study found no differences in histology between fish fed GM vs non-GM soybean diets [928]. For plant-based protein sources, studies from Norway reported mixed growth outcomes: some studies found decreased growth rates with plant-based proteins, while other studies found similar growth rates to fish meal diets [924]. Four replicated, controlled studies (three randomised) from Norway and Scotland found reduced final body weights with plant-based protein diets, while two controlled studies (one replicated) from Norway found similar final body weights to fish meal [924]. In Norway, two replicated, controlled studies (one randomised) found lowered feeding efficiency with plant-based protein diets, whereas one replicated study found increased feeding efficiency [924]. Two randomised, replicated, controlled studies in Scotland and Norway reported similar digestibility between plant and fish meal diets [924]. One replicated, controlled experiment in Norway using the yeast Yarrowia lipolytica reported no differences in weight compared to a fishmeal control [920].

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "Norway Atlantic salmon alternative feed components studies evidence", "k": 3, "offset": 0}
{"query_string":"Norway Atlantic salmon alternative feed components studies evidence","k": 3, "offset": 3}
{"action_id":"928"}
{"action_id":"924"}

query: What are the effects of altering the physical environment of salmon cages, such as their size or lighting, on salmon health in aquaculture?
relevant_summary: A replicated, controlled study in Norway reported that salmon kept under low-intensity artificial light or natural lighting had fewer lice, and lice numbers increased with higher artificial light intensity [741]. A replicated study in Australia recorded lower levels of amoebic gill disease in salmon held in larger cages compared to smaller cages [742].

query: How do different non-chemical water-based treatments, such as fallowing and freshwater bathing, compare in their reported effectiveness for specific diseases in salmon?
relevant_summary: Freshwater bathing showed mixed effectiveness against amoebic gill disease (AGD): one study reported reduced amoebae on gills lasting up to 10 days after treatment, while a replicated, controlled study found no difference between treated and untreated salmon (739). Fallowing showed reduced parasite loads for sea lice in Scotland, but an Australian study reported no difference in mortality from AGD in cages where fallowing had been used (1026).

query: Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?
relevant_summary: Replicated and controlled studies report no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight for several options: dietary supplementation with phytase and phosphate resulted in no difference in weight gain compared to no supplementation, with one study finding greater final weights with phytase, and taurine supplementation showed no difference in weight gain [930]. Two replicated studies found similar final weight gain when fish meal was replaced with a krill meal substitute, with de-shelled krill producing growth rates closer to fish meal than whole krill [916]. For plant-based proteins, multiple replicated/controlled studies reported similar growth rates and similar final body weights to fish meal diets, although other studies reported reductions [924]. For bacterial protein, two replicated, controlled studies found similar growth rates when up to 25% of fish meal was replaced, while another study reported higher growth at 18% and 36% bacterial protein; however, a 50% replacement reduced growth [918].

{"action_id":"930"}
{"action_id":"916"}
{"action_id":"924"}

{"query":"Which dietary alternatives or supplements to traditional fish meal have been shown to have no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight?","summary":"Replicated and controlled studies report no negative impact on Atlantic salmon growth or weight for several options: dietary supplementation with phytase and phosphate resulted in no difference in weight gain compared to no supplementation, with one study finding greater final weights with phytase, and taurine supplementation showed no difference in weight gain [930]. Two replicated studies found similar final weight gain when fish meal was replaced with a krill meal substitute, with de-shelled krill producing growth rates closer to fish meal than whole krill [916]. For plant-based proteins, multiple replicated/controlled studies reported similar growth rates and similar final body weights to fish meal diets, although other studies reported reductions [924]. For bacterial protein, two replicated, controlled studies found similar growth rates when up to 25% of fish meal was replaced, while another study reported higher growth at 18% and 36% bacterial protein; however, a 50% replacement reduced growth [918].","action_ids":["930","916","924","918"]}
